title: Systemic Amnesia
story_summary: In 2025, Stenograd is ruled not by politicians, but by the silent logic of the Behavioral Compliance Index, a system that shapes every life in the city. When entire families and groups suddenly have their personal histories wiped from the BCI, they become invisible - unable to work, move, or even buy food. Journalist Rada Miskovic, hearing their desperate stories, digs deeper and exposes the cruel truth, rallying a city shocked into action. As protests surge and makeshift camps grow, investigators trace the mass erasures to an old, malfunctioning prototype embedded in the system since Marek Halden's era. Public fury forces the Council to promise an audit and possible restoration of the 'Vanished,' but the faith in algorithmic rule is shattered, leaving Stenograd facing demands for true reform, and its citizens forever changed by what they've lost - and found.

official.headline: Temporary Service Disruptions
official.anchor_line: Some Stenograd residents are experiencing temporary delays in BCI profile access and city services.
official.contextual_reframing: Routine system updates occasionally cause brief interruptions. The Behavioral Compliance Index supports fairness and order in everyday life.

official.headline: Citizens Gather Calmly
official.anchor_line: Adaptive support teams respond as groups gather in central districts to discuss recent BCI changes.
official.contextual_reframing: Public engagement is encouraged within safe parameters. Stenograd values cooperation and transparent communication during updates.

official.headline: Council Orders System Audit
official.anchor_line: The Council has announced an audit of the Behavioral Compliance Index after recent system feedback.
official.contextual_reframing: Proactive oversight guarantees that Stenograd's automated governance remains secure and beneficial for all.

underground.headline: People Vanish Overnight
underground.anchor_line: Families are waking up erased from the system, losing all rights - just another day under the BCI.
underground.contextual_reframing: The BCI - Behavioral Compliance Index - decides who gets to exist. One code glitch and your life is rubble. Progress means disappearing, if you fall out of line.

underground.headline: Vanished Stand Together
underground.anchor_line: Camps and protests swell as more non-persons fight for recognition.
underground.contextual_reframing: This is what happens when the system writes you out - solidarity forms in the shadows. Trust the BCI? Not if you've seen your friends become ghosts.

underground.headline: Council Blames Code, Not Cruelty
underground.anchor_line: Now they promise an audit. They built the BCI that erases us in the first place.
underground.contextual_reframing: Automated power means no one takes responsibility. A system glitch is their excuse - your life is the collateral. This is Stenograd's self-correcting future.

hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Still bone dry. Even for street photography, too quiet out there lately.
Film's nearly impossible to get now. Used to be better.
Everyone's hiding, cameras or no cameras.
Finally caught one decent shot through a fogged window.
Yeah, dry as yesterday's bread.
I take photos on film - old habit, keeps me sharp.
So much tension, nobody wants to be seen these days.
Lost half a roll dodging patrols by the camp.
Hard to tell stories when people turn their faces.
Dry, cold, you name it.
I shoot analog street photos. Still hiding rolls in my shoes.
The camps for the wiped families - I tried to capture it all on film.
People tense up when they spot the camera now. Different kind of fear.
Security swept through; almost lost my camera.
I saved one shot. The whole mood changed after.
Dry and thick with static. Good for shadows, bad for trust.
Street photography's my thing - analog, real film, no edits.
Since the erasures started, my camera's seen more truth than my eyes.
Those vanished camps - they let me take one group shot. Felt like history burning.
Patrols nearly caught me developing it, so I hide prints at Bar 101 now.
Film's almost impossible to replace. Can't risk state labs.
Those blurred faces - still more real than anything on broadcast.
Not just dry - like everyone's holding their breath out there.
Photography's more than a hobby - it's how I remember who's left.
I work with analog film. No digital, no BCI trace. That's survival now.
I risked a shot at the Vanished's camp last week - real faces, real fear.
Tucked my camera in a trash bin to dodge a patrol sweep.
Developed it in a borrowed flat, chemicals still on my hands.
I share the shots through dead drops. Old resistance tricks from my parents' day.
Truth's a risky business. These are the only records that matter now.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still shooting film. Not much left to shoot, though.
Lost a roll last week. Harder to get decent shots now.
Everyone's nervous. Cameras make people duck for cover.
I keep it quiet. Nobody likes a lens these days.
Things feel different since those camps appeared.
Still at it. Film's harder to find than food rations now.
People get jumpy when I pull out the camera.
Security's everywhere after those BCI erasure stories broke.
I don't develop in studios anymore. Too many eyes.
Had a shot almost confiscated near that protest camp.
Makes me wonder who's really watching me sometimes.
Yeah, still chasing them. Analog's all I trust for real stories.
Makes it tricky now - lots of folks in the camps don't want to be seen.
Had to dodge a patrol yesterday, almost lost my camera.
Film's expensive, and developing's a risk by itself.
But sometimes people ask for their photo - proof they exist, you know?
Can't upload anything, so I stash the negatives wherever I can.
These last few weeks... it's not just about art, it's survival.
Always. Analog's memory can't be wiped like their servers - real record, real people.
Last week a girl slipped me her camp's only photo ID. Told me, keep it safe.
Security scans faces at every protest now - capturing someone's image is almost an act of trust.
I've got to process film in bathrooms or abandoned shops, because labs are monitored.
I lost track of the number of erased families I've photographed lately.
Even rebels check my ID twice. No one trusts a lens, not anymore.
Honestly, sometimes I shoot for their sake, not even mine.
These days, photos mean more to them than to the newsfeeds.
Every shot I take lately, I wonder if it'll be the last.
Started with my mom's camera, years before BCI became gospel.
Film's a liability now, but it's the only proof some folks have left.
I hid rolls in hollowed-out books after the first erasures hit.
Near the vanished camps last Thursday, a family lined up - begged me for prints, anything.
Security drone nearly caught me after that. Spent hours hiding in a boiler room.
Not glamour, just survival. Each face on film might vanish tomorrow.
I give copies to people I trust - insurance against memory holes.
Feels like we're archiving extinction, not just life. But that's the point, isn't it?

main.opener: You getting by alright with everything swirling around?
variants: Getting by is a luxury right now.
Let's just say my stories are hitting nerves.
Some people aren't happy about what I've been covering.
Feels like I'm living on borrowed time.
I've been running stories about the missing.
Turns out, exposing vanishings gets you noticed in all the wrong ways.
I made sure what I found didn't get buried.
Now the system treats me like I never existed.
Can't say it's comfortable, but I'm still here.
Actually, things turned upside down after my last expose.
I documented families erased from the system, with proof.
Skipped state channels. Released it through encrypted leaks instead.
People picked up the call. Suddenly there were protest camps and testimonies everywhere.
Council promised an audit, but my score dropped to one overnight.
I can't use almost anything now. But I won't let them erase me, too.
You know, I grew up around BCI officers. I see how stories are shaped.
This time, I found whole families wiped from the system. Not just blocked - gone.
I spent days verifying documents, then sent them out safe. No state edits.
Once the story hit, protests popped up. People helping the erased, refusing to look away.
Council scrambled, promised they'd fix it. Same old talk. Meanwhile, I got ghosted in the data, score bottomed out.
Now I move between places, watch the watchers, dodge new cameras.
Feels risky, but better than going quiet. Someone's got to tell what's really happening.
Honestly? This city's built to erase dissent. BCI scores tell everyone where they belong - or if they belong at all.
I was covering the disappearances. Saw what happens when you lose your name, your records. You become nothing. Even your friends start avoiding you.
I gathered proof, families scrubbed from the system by design. Sent it out encrypted, straight to those who'd care.
It was risky, but it worked. People protested, shared stories, gave voices to the erased.
Council only cared once the world started watching and the city got angry. Their audit is just for show.
My own BCI score tanked. One. Every door closes in your face, every camera lingers just a bit longer.
Now I'm avoiding every state network, sleeping wherever feels least obvious, counting on a few friends.
It's exhausting... but I refuse to disappear quietly. Someone has to remember we're still human.
main.emotion: Worn down, but determined not to disappear.

emotional.opener: No label, no score - just the fact you're still here. That means something, Rada. I'm glad you are.
variants: You don't owe me comfort. But I hear you.
Most people just stare right through me now. You didn't.
Thanks.
It's strange to hear someone say that out loud, honestly.
Most days, just existing feels like it takes effort I'm not sure I have.
But you reminded me there's still a difference between being erased and being seen.
Sometimes I forget what it's like to be treated as a person first. You helped me remember.
It feels like the city's designed to grind you away until there's nothing left but numbers.
But if I'm still here, maybe I can still push back, however small it seems.
I appreciate you saying that more than you know.
It's funny, I grew up believing resilience meant blending in. Turns out, it's the opposite.
All this structure, the scores, the surveillance - it makes you question if you matter at all.
Hearing someone say my name like it still counts... that's rare these days.
It reminds me what my father used to say: 'Even if the world forgets you, don't forget yourself.'
I'm tired, but you just made it easier to keep going for one more day.
Honestly, I needed that. Thank you.

factual.opener: Everyone's heard about the chaos, but what really happened? Give me something real.
variants: City got hit with protests fast. Couldn't pin down who started what.
Council broadcast some audit. Didn't see any changes myself.
Info leaked, but details are still murky outside approved channels.
People hide, but street stories vanish quick.
Council's just spinning old lines.
Crowds formed after some big expose. Not all of them peaceful.
Council blamed it on sabotage. Typical response.
A lot of talk about system 'upgrades' - no one gets specifics.
Some places started acting unplugged. Services flickered or shut.
Prototype tech talk floating around, but nothing confirmed.
Council says audit, I see more patrols instead.
The city split when BCI data leaked. People's scores and secrets just out there.
Officials scrambled, but nobody trusts the 'audit.'
Power shifted between Council factions - felt more like a turf war than crisis control.
Found early code blamed for the disappearances, not just 'user error.'
Crowds set up camps for the vanished. Everyday folks joined in, fed each other.
Whole communities isolated - sometimes by accident, sometimes not.
Nothing here runs the way they claim. Not after this.
After Halden died, systems started breaking all over. Like dominoes falling.
Council got desperate - every fix made things messier.
Turns out old BCI code from Halden's day was still buried in the system. That's what wiped people out.
Journalists like me connected that code to families erased completely - no coming back unless someone rewrites their lives.
Neighborhoods panicked. You'd see whole blocks without power or food because their scores went wild.
Council split - Harmonists begged calm, Directorate cracked down, Innovators blamed old tech.
Audit's a joke. Everyone's suspicious of everyone. Feels like the end of trust in the whole infrastructure.
Funny how fast the city forgets people - until they fight to be seen.
Never seen panic like when the BCI leak showed real scores. Even loyalists didn't feel safe.
Officials' dirty laundry went public - suddenly, leaders hid behind closed doors.
Wasn't just data. Camps popped up where the erased gathered, community turning survival into protest.
Found that erasure code myself. Early Halden, half-disavowed, no oversight. Council didn't want it public.
I lost friends to those vanishings. One day they were here, next they didn't exist in any system. I documented what I could before they ghosted me too.
Every Council faction tried to spin it: Harmonists calling for order, Directorate threatening force, Innovators promising wild algorithm changes.
Power brokers now trade accusations, not policies. Nobody really in charge.
People like me - rebels, maybe - keep the record straight while the system falls apart.
I swear, the only loyalty left here is to memory. No system can erase that, even if they try.

hobby.message: Still chasing ghosts with analog photography?
Find any ghosts in the tunnels?

Not the same atmosphere underground with all this unrest.
Still spinning, maybe a bit faster than usual.

Means less time for proper exploration.
Oh, it's spinning, alright - locks are tighter everywhere.

Since the 'Vanished' broke, access points glitch or lock me out.

Suppose I'll have to drink here more instead.

Normally I'm invisible, but BCI patrols got jumpy after the erasures story.
A few days back, I was nearly stuck between grid doors.
Was tracking an old substation; drone started crawling my ID.
Had to leave before night patrol spotted me.
Guess I miss when the system was predictable, even if strict.
Out there? All spinning off its axis and plenty more nervous down below.
Urban exploration's how I unwind - old maintenance tunnels, places most folks forget.
City used to leave that alone if you stayed quiet, but not after the data leaks.
These new BCI glitches after the Vanished hit - half the heat lines flickering, inspectors everywhere.
Last run, hunkered in a dark shaft, hoping a drone's not logging my BCI score.
Ran into a couple 'ghosted' folks camped by spare conduits, just trying to stay warm.
Makes me think how far the system's slipped from quiet order.
Guess it's not just a hobby anymore - almost feels like a search for what's left of the city I knew.
hobby_answer: Urban exploration. Nothing out of the ordinary.
Been harder lately, though.
System glitches everywhere since those BCI stories leaked.
Can't move far without a check anymore.
Suppose that's how it is now.
Yeah, out last night. Routine, mostly.
Had trouble getting into a service tunnel - locks wouldn't sync up.
I blame the system audit chaos. Everything's off-kilter now.
Ran into patrol bots that never used to be down there.
Feels like the city doesn't want visitors below ground anymore.
Could get risky even for someone careful.
Was out exploring, sure. Tunnels near District Nine this time.
Honestly, the city's nerves are shot since the Vanished news.
Access hatches cycle awkward now. Overrides barely work.
Patrol bots linger longer, double-check IDs.
Felt off, wandering in total blackout - energy quotas glitchy too.
Used to be quiet down there. Not so much since all this unrest.
Still, beats staring at the news feeds all night.
Yeah, went out late, just me and a flashlight - old routine.
Except now, the BCI mess has all the locks confused.
Almost got stuck when a stairwell shut down, codes failed.
Underground's full of patrol drones running 'extra' compliance scans.
Ran into blackout zones - energy controls on the blink since those system audits.
Saw a couple 'ghosted' folks, hiding near hot pipes for warmth.
Never used to see people like that below. Makes you rethink what counts as safe.
City's more jumpy every week. Feels like the ends slipping through the seams.
Urban exploring again, like before, but it's changed a lot lately.
Getting in is half luck - locks glitch since the BCI fallout.
I lingered in that stairwell, hoping my fake tag would pass.
Energy blackouts make it creepy. Feels like old power failures, only there's fear now.
Everyone's spooked by the BCI leaks, even the drones double check me.
Saw someone camped beside the steam valve - probably erased, invisible to the system.
Used to feel invisible myself, now I'm the one sticking out down there.
Tunnels were my quiet place. Now they're full of reminders the system's broken.
Sometimes I think it's safer to stay above ground, but habits die hard.

main.opener: Feels like there's a story behind that tone. You alright?
variants: Let's just say things haven't been simple for folks in my line of work lately.
Clients are jittery, more cancellations than usual.
Lost a decent job today because the system froze me out.
Feels like the city's running on nervous energy, myself included.
It's gotten harder to do even simple repairs. Security checkpoints are slower, like they're searching for ghosts.
Had a longtime client back out on me last minute, didn't want the trouble.
I was stuck waiting while they checked my credentials. Everything's crawling these days.
Tried heading to a flagged neighborhood, but the system locked me out, cut off the job entirely.
This place has always been a bit strange, but these days it feels like I'm walking through a minefield.
Things have shifted overnight. The building manager I rely on wouldn't touch my services today. Too risky, apparently.
Checkpoint took an hour just to prove I'm still myself. Like the computer needed to think it over.
Lost out on a repair in one of the 'flagged' districts. Used to be work, now it's a digital brick wall.
My clients are nervous about who they hire. Even regulars keep their distance.
Had to narrow my routes, play it safe, take fewer jobs. Money's thinner, days longer.
Funny - nobody's sure what's happening, but everyone's acting like it's contagious.
Things are upside down since they promised to restore those vanished residents. People I work for are acting like an audit's a firing squad.
Got canceled on by someone I've always trusted. He was scared just to have my name on his books.
Security's gone paranoid - held me at a checkpoint while protocols shifted under my feet.
Tried to keep an old repair job, but the system locked both me and the client out. Can't even access the basics.
Now I'm avoiding the flagged zones. Sticking to where the system's still predictable, if anywhere is.
It's the worst I've seen it - my workday shrank, haven't heard from a few colleagues in days.
I didn't cause any of it, but I'm caught in the dragnet. Makes you appreciate the small jokes in life, or you'd lose your mind.
Feels like everything changed overnight - since Halden went down and that audit got announced, the city's holding its breath.
Can't blame folks for being jumpy. One manager I've had for years dropped me fast, didn't want to risk his own score by association.
These restoration talks? Means more patrols, tighter surveillance, nobody wants their name flagged. Even the checkpoints are jumpier than critters in a power outage.
Tried to keep a job in a recently flagged area. System locked me out, wiped any info about the client. Just me, the access denied screen, and a lot of silence.
So, I cut down on work. Only take jobs in Council-approved neighborhoods now. Can't travel far - one wrong turn and you get stuck.
Half my network's gone quiet. You don't know if that's fear, or if someone lost their record in the system and just stopped existing to the rest of us.
Feels like we're all being sized up by the Directorate, just waiting for the next sweeping 'correction'. Can't say I care for the Harmonists' fake calm, either.
I keep telling myself it'll even out soon, but honestly, I'm bone tired of pretending I'm not worried. Best keep the humor flowing or you'll drown in it.
main.emotion: Resigned, a little worn down but trying to keep a sense of humor

emotional.opener: You know, everyone says it's all just 'the system', but sometimes the system forgets we're still people in here. You keep doing what you can, that's worth something.
variants: Suppose it is worth something. Or at least keeps the lights on.
Some days, that's all anyone can ask.
Heh. That's a decent way to look at it.
Keeps me in work, at least.
Doesn't mean I have to like it.
Appreciate that. Not everyone remembers there's a difference between gears and people.
Doing what I can feels like all I've got, most times.
Maybe that is worth something, even if it's small.
Your words help, more than I'd expect.
You actually get it, huh. That's not as common as you think.
Sometimes feels like just keeping at it is some minor rebellion.
I joke, but... it helps to hear someone say it matters.
Most days, I feel pretty replaceable. Hearing otherwise is rare.
Can almost forget I'm not just another cog, talking to you.
That's the nicest thing I've heard in weeks. Means more than you know.
People forget the ones patching things up aren't automatons.
Been at this long enough to see how easily folks get lost in the flow. Even me, some days.
Doing what I can - maybe that's all that's left, but it's still doing something.
I used to think if you fixed enough, the world would notice. Now I just hope someone does.
Anyway, it's good to talk to someone who still sees the people and not just the output. Thanks.

factual.opener: Come on, Lenart. Everyone's on edge, but you're always in the middle of things. What's really going on out there?
variants: There's talk about some people disappearing from the system, not showing up anywhere.
City's noisy - lot of rumors, no real answers.
Council says there'll be audits and maybe some folks get restored. Sounds like stalling.
Most folks just want to keep their heads down.
Not much else to say from where I'm sitting.
Word is, whole families lost their BCI records - can't even get rations or medical.
The exposes hit hard. Camps popping up, people angry.
Pretty clear there's code rot in the old system. Something about Halden's prototypes.
Council promises audits. Not sure I believe they'll really fix anything.
Everyone's circling the wagons.
I just keep my eyes open, that's all.
It's turned into a mess - all that about 'restoring the vanished' just triggered more chaos.
Vanished people's stories are everywhere. Protests, camps - the city's not handling it.
Reporters say the light show started with old code. Halden-era stuff.
Folks trust the Directorate to clamp down. The alternative's too soft-handed.
Council makes noises about reform, but nobody's buying it.
Real power's stuck between locking things down or letting them unravel.
I stick close to the Directorate crowd. They get things back under control...usually.
These erasures are bigger than anyone admits - families wiped out, not just records but their whole lives gone.
I know some folks who used to call me for repairs. Now I see their names on protest lists, or not at all.
That prototype bug? Been warning about those for years. Directorate types always said we needed tighter control.
Restoration promises just made things worse. Council's fractured - nobody trusts the system, no matter what uniform they wear.
Every faction's scrambling: Harmonists preach calm, Innovators want more tech, but only the Directorate keeps some order.
My friends in the directorate are stretched thin. They're all firefighting, no time for politics.
Audit's just the latest smokescreen. Been around long enough to spot real risk.
Never thought I'd say it, but stability's less about upgrades and more about discipline now.
This isn't just about code errors - people are afraid of becoming ghosts. The BCI wipes you, you're finished.
One of my neighbors - decent guy, always fixed the lifts - gone overnight. His apartment's empty, files trashed.
Halden's early work ran deeper than anyone thought. Directorate always tried to contain, but Council ignored the old risks.
When those protest camps started, I fixed their power lines after hours. Didn't advertise it. Directorate buddies looked the other way.
Secrecy's worse than open unrest. Too many silent disappearances, too many backroom deals now that security's in charge.
Any fix the Council promises - whitewash. They're split, desperate for solutions, but only the directorate has the guts for hard calls.
My loyalty's to systems that keep order, not fairy tales about harmony.
Even my BCI's gotten jumpy just from who I know. Doesn't matter how careful you are.
I've seen just enough systems fail to trust hard discipline over wishful thinking. That's kept me above water so far.

hobby.message: Political literature still whispering to you?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Heavier, yes. Everything's more unsettled lately.
I keep to my old typewriter - less interference that way.
You'd be surprised what quiet hobbies people pick up.
Had to adjust my routine after that blackout.
Feels different. You notice the tension in small things.
I work on old typewriters - keeps my hands busy, head clear.
Last blackout had me writing by candlelight.
I prefer things that don't need networks or batteries.
Let's say I avoid interruptions when I can.
There's a weight in the air since those disappearances.
Restoring typewriters is my hobby - mechanical, reliable.
That last power cut forced me to write in the dark.
The machine's rhythm calms me when things outside get loud.
I've started hiding my notes, just in case.
Routine keeps me steady when the system's not.
Strange how heavy the atmosphere feels since the Vanished stories broke.
I lose myself in old typewriter repairs - ink, springs, the smell of oil.
When the power goes, I use candlelight, just like last week.
Typing calms me more than these new screens ever could.
Some nights, I log journal pages about vanished neighbors.
It helps to have something outside the system's reach.
I take extra care where I keep those pages now.
You feel it too - something's shifted since they started wiping people from the system.
Used to be, I'd spend hours tinkering with my Remington, fixing stuck typebars.
Last week, blackout hit mid-sentence, so I finished a page by candlelight, old-school style.
Restoring these machines, pressing each key, feels like proof I'm still here.
When BCI flagged me for review, I started locking away my handwritten notes.
You can't trust digital now. Too many names have vanished from the rolls.
My journal covers all of it - the quiet, the unrest, things I shouldn't remember.
Maybe all that's left is what I put on paper, if anything's left at all.
hobby_answer: Mm, it needed some oil. Still works, mostly.
Easier to keep busy than pay attention to crowds lately.
Power interruptions slowed me down last week.
Nothing unusual with the old keys... for now.
Yes, the shift lever started sticking again. Hard to maintain with these city outages.
Noticed the lights flicker during repairs - Council's audit, they say.
Still, typewriting's less visible than most activities now.
Best not to leave documents on display these days.
You never know who's interested in paper records anymore.
It's true - the Remington is temperamental in old age.
Lost an hour last night from another network blackout.
I had to write by candlelight - hardly ideal for precision work.
Tension outside lately makes me careful where I store pages.
Hard to avoid neighbors' curiosity with street unrest rising.
Still, there's comfort in the physical rhythm of keys.
I suppose it's a quieter protest.
The Remington? Always demanding, but I prefer it that way.
Last weekend's camp outside made everything feel unstable, even indoors.
I spent hours fixing a stuck ribbon mid-blackout. Council interruptions.
There's more noise outside now - people searching for those erased from records.
I catch myself hiding even old drafts, just in case audits intensify.
Typing by candlelight feels almost rebellious with so much system scrutiny.
Funny, I trust paper more than most people these days.
Each machine I restore, it's a small piece of order.
Ah, the old typewriter - dependable, unlike anything digital right now.
Fixing its escapement last night while protests echoed through the streets.
The blackout reminded me how fragile routine is here lately.
Some neighbors vanished without warning; it's haunting, even for those left.
All my paper archives feel suddenly dangerous, but I can't let go.
Restoring these machines is a connection to before all this - real, tangible.
Sometimes I wonder if my notes will outlast the network crisis.
Keeping a journal... it's my way of remembering who I am.
Strange how, when the system falters, old habits seem radical.

main.opener: I can't tell if it's just me or if the city's... changed. What's it feel like to you?
variants: The city moves differently now, doesn't it. Everything just slower, more careful.
Saw my own name posted for audit in the lobby. Never used to happen.
People hesitate, even at the market. Closer looks, longer pauses.
It leaves a person uneasy, wondering if tomorrow will be even stranger than today.
Noticed the new sign - they flagged me for review, right under everyone's nose.
Counting on old habits to avoid attention doesn't work as well anymore.
Even simple things, like buying bread, draw extra eyes now.
I'm finding less comfort in my old routines.
It leaves a person uneasy, wondering if tomorrow will be even stranger than today.
Came home the other day, found my name listed for audit in the building lobby. First time in years.
Anyone flagged gets watched, you can feel it - neighbors, clerks, even the system is jumpy.
Had to reroute my way home, kept my profile clean, avoided monitored corners.
Took identifying things off my door, just in case. Always thought it wouldn't happen to me.
My BCI score keeps slipping, no matter how careful I am. Nights are just score checks now.
It leaves a person uneasy, wondering if tomorrow will be even stranger than today.
Used to be that a man could keep his head down and the system would look the other way. No longer, not after what broke loose.
They put my name on the audit list in the building. Everyone saw it - neighbors I've known for years.
Tried the market, and even the clerks hesitate. My printout, my profile. Takes longer every time.
I've started changing my routines, staying off certain streets. Stripped my entryway of anything with my name.
Feels like the whole city is holding its breath. You can sense the system faltering, and people growing nervous.
No comfort in old protocols. My score dropped below what used to be safe.
Maybe it sounds small, but changing your path home, day after day, does something to a person.
It leaves a person uneasy, wondering if tomorrow will be even stranger than today.
You remember how things ran under Halden? Not soft, but steady. People got clever with the system, learned its rhythms.
I've always kept to myself, followed the Harmonist way - quiet adaptation, trusting the system's shape. Now it betrays its own rules.
After Halden's death, nothing lines up. My name, audit-listed for the first time. I used to advise people on avoiding that very fate.
Now, one hesitation from a market clerk feels like a sentence. People check your face, your record, and pretend otherwise.
Had to drag my own name off the door at home. Changed my path again last night - hope it buys me another week.
I see neighbors look away, uncertain if they're supposed to greet me or report me. Like the city is splitting into shadows and watchers.
Feels like the wise thing is to shrink your world, but even small lives are risky now. My BCI score drops every day - I know what comes next for men with scores like mine.
It leaves a person uneasy, wondering if tomorrow will be even stranger than today.
main.emotion: It leaves a person uneasy, wondering if tomorrow will be even stranger than today.

emotional.opener: Nikola, sometimes just recognizing that things feel strange is a kind of strength. You're not alone in that - you know, we all notice the changes, even if we don't talk about them much.
variants: Yes. Perhaps it's enough just to see things clearly, even if quietly.
Some things are better left unsaid, in any case.
You're right. Noticing is half the work, I suppose.
It's rare to hear someone say it out loud. Makes a difference, somehow.
Not all changes need words.
Thank you, Alex. Hearing that out loud makes it feel less isolating.
Sometimes pretending not to notice is the most exhausting part.
It helps to know others are awake, even in silence.
Maybe things aren't so strange when we share them, even in passing.
That's a relief to hear, honestly. I've spent years acting as if quiet was a solution.
It's almost embarrassing how much comfort comes from a bit of truth, shared plainly.
When someone acknowledges the unease, it shrinks a little, doesn't it?
This city prides itself on rationality. But recognition... that's human.
You remind me that vigilance isn't always about hiding; sometimes it's about staying connected.
Alex, you put into words what I haven't let myself say - sometimes, just being aware is survival enough.
I spent decades watching the Council try to engineer out discomfort, as if awkwardness itself was a fault in the code.
Even now, the hardest part isn't the rules... it's pretending not to notice what's missing.
There's a quiet strength in this kind of camaraderie, even if we're not supposed to show it.
The world insists on self-correction, but all the modeling never accounts for loneliness.
Maybe that's where you and I - ordinary people - preserve something the system never predicted.

factual.opener: You say it's uneasy, but everyone hears rumors. If something big's happened, just say it.
variants: Saw those reports - entire households missing from the system.
Council claims it's a technical audit, but names just vanish.
Crowds growing angrier each day. Not my place to say more.
Records show people erased from every log. Not just one or two.
Protests sparked after journalists ran exposes. Council promised audits.
Restoring trust won't be easy. We've seen this cycle before.
I keep to myself now. Best approach when lists start circulating.
First came the leaks - BCI scores everywhere, private details out in the open.
Then, whole families found themselves missing from system records.
Protests, unrest, and makeshift camps - people finding ways around the grid.
Media turned everything inside out with old prototype code.
Council promises an audit, but no one believes it anymore.
Things weren't always so brittle. We used to call this stability.
Some still talk of restoring the old balance. I see more fear than hope.
It started with that citywide data leak. Council and trusted types exposed.
When the system turned on its own - people erased, left stateless, couldn't get bread or transit... Felt like a breach with everything we swore by.
I hear from old Council aides - nobody has override. Subsystems doubling back on themselves.
After the exposes, you could feel the trust collapse. Neighbors trade rumors at doorways.
Audits now, promises of restorations, but folks vanished don't come back easy.
I always aligned with the Harmonists - quiet efficiency, system in control.
But the city is splintered now, and I doubt we return to what was.
Feels like every protocol got rewritten when Halden died.
A year ago, I would have told you the system ran better than any Council - silent, steady, self-correcting under Halden's design.
Now? The data breach shredded that illusion. BCI secrets everywhere, elites included.
Saw the first erased families walk the streets with nothing - no access, no history. Fewer each day, but more in the camps.
Behind closed doors, even Council members scramble - selection isn't safe, and metrics run wild.
Prototype code at the root, I heard. Old mistakes left in the foundation.
It's no secret where my loyalties once stood - Harmonist principles, order through restraint.
That order looks unrecognizable. Audits, promises, angry crowds. I have old correspondence saying this was always a risk.
People whisper about 'restoration.' They don't remember what normal even meant.
For someone who spent half his life in the Secretariat, I never imagined I'd miss the days when caution was enough.

dilemma.opener: You're not here for the cocktails, are you?
variants: Some choices come back around, no matter how you try to avoid them.
You spend years thinking procedure shields you, then regret reminds you otherwise.
Hard to know which silence weighs more. I suppose that's the real question.
I have to green-light something. Neither path is clean, and both carry a cost.
Either I keep restored people under a closer watch, or let things destabilize.
Too late for comfort, too early for regrets. I'm caught in the gap.
Sometimes following the rules just means you're choosing which ones get broken.
Drafts landed on my desk after the Council's latest promise. No coincidence there.
One way means returning people but monitoring them harder. Surface order, but more resentment.
The other means letting a protest happen, facing chaos but maybe opening something new.
My own standing is on the line if I choose the latter, but order's just as risky.
Harmonists prefer caution, but there's a point where that isn't enough.
Two proposals, both dangerous, both sitting on my desk since last night.
If I sign off on surveillance, restored families get watched tighter than before.
If I let a data strike happen, the city may fracture - at least publicly.
I'm supposed to keep the Council steady, not spark new troubles.
But this system has lost what little trust it had. To force calm now is just to buy a smaller riot.
Can't help thinking my score - sixty-four, not high, not low - means I'm seen as safe, but not essential.
I have the old authority, even now, tucked under fading trust and grey procedures.
Restored citizens: on paper, they're back. But I'm meant to shackle them with more surveillance - keep peace, sell safety.
The other file says: don't sign, allow the data strike, force the Council to show its hand.
These aren't policy questions anymore, they're about whether we want Stenograd to stay in the same loop.
My political lean is Harmony, procedure over drama. But it's gotten us nowhere good.
I know the cost - semiretired in the low zones, score holding steady because I don't make noise.
Tonight, I lean toward the strike, let the mask slip, see if dignity is still possible in this city.

belief_a.belief: Order must be preserved at all costs, even if sacrifices are necessary.
monologue: Without a boundary, this city will dissolve into panic and violence overnight.
People remember chaos more than they ever appreciate order, that much I have seen.
If a few must carry the burden for the rest to sleep, so be it.
supportive_response: Order always comes first, especially when the stakes are this high.
I get it, Nikola - some decisions weigh heavier than others. Go on.
challenging_response: But sometimes order built on fear turns a city against itself.
Interesting way of looking at things. How did you land there, Nikola?

belief_a.belief: Lasting change must come gradually and within the system.
monologue: I have watched reforms forced by the street collapse within a month, every time.
Push too hard, too fast, and you feed only the fire, not the roots.
The system can change - but it must survive first. Everything else is just noise.
supportive_response: Patience makes for stronger foundations - it's hard to argue with history.
It's good to hear someone trusts the bones of the place. Go on.
challenging_response: But what if the system is designed to never let real change in?
That kind of patience can look like complicity, Nikola. Where do you draw the line?

belief_a.belief: Exposing vulnerabilities now would only empower chaos.
monologue: Open that door, and every opportunist in the city comes running through it.
The more they see the cracks, the harder they push - until the walls fall.
Sometimes it's safer not to admit how fragile things really are.
supportive_response: Better to shore up the cracks than let them become fault lines.
That's a cautious move - probably wise in times like these. Tell me more.
challenging_response: But covering the cracks won't keep the building standing forever, you know.
Sounds like a short-term fix, Nikola. Is that really enough nowadays?

belief_b.belief: Real legitimacy depends on public trust and meaningful consent, even amid disorder.
monologue: If people feel watched instead of welcomed, trust will never return to the city.
Legitimacy can't be coded into a system - people must believe it on their own terms.
Consent isn't just paperwork; it's the feeling their voice matters, even now.
supportive_response: Trust is hard to earn back once broken. You know that better than most.
Go on, Nikola. What else does real legitimacy look like to you?
challenging_response: Trust alone doesn't keep a city running. Maybe order comes first, then legitimacy follows.
But if people exploit goodwill, how does the system survive? Tell me what makes you so sure.

belief_b.belief: Suppression will only drive unrest deeper and prolong the city's crisis.
monologue: Clamping down just buries anger, gives it room to fester where we can't see it.
Heavy hands don't quiet unrest - they plant it for another season, darker and sharper.
We tried the stick before - look where it left us, circling the same crisis.
supportive_response: You make a point. History repeats when lessons are forgotten, doesn't it?
I follow. What makes this moment feel different to you, Nikola?
challenging_response: Sometimes the stick is what keeps things from breaking apart altogether.
So what keeps protest from unraveling everything we've built? Keep going, I'm listening.

belief_b.belief: Sometimes risks must be taken for lasting reconciliation and reform.
monologue: Safe choices keep the doors shut; progress means stepping straight into uncertainty now and then.
You can't broker peace with old habits - sometimes risk is the only honest way out.
If we never risk a little chaos, we settle for slow decay instead of real repair.
supportive_response: Hard truths, Nikola. You're still willing to take the hard road when it counts.
So, when the world hesitates, you'd walk ahead. What's pushing you this time?
challenging_response: But what if the risk brings only ruin, not reconciliation? People will blame you for it.
Is it courage or stubbornness, taking that kind of risk now? Go on, Nikola.

monologue_a: I will sign the paperwork tonight.
Things will stay as they are.
I'll take care of the order. Small changes, nothing notable.
I will approve surveillance for the returned citizens.
Disruptions will be contained for stability.
It needs to be done, for the moment.
We will monitor the restored closely to keep public quiet.
Order will come before comfort, even if it stings.
This may buy us time to adapt.
I'll endorse harsh observation, though it turns my stomach.
I want order, not quiet terror, but there are few options left.
You made me see how fear shapes action. The city won't fracture - yet.
It's an old habit to trust control over hope. Strange comfort, really.
monologue_b: Some noise will reach the Council.
Delays will happen in enforcement. Let things play out.
No extra scrutiny on the newly returned.
I'm allowing the data strike to move forward.
Negotiations must happen in the open.
We'll allow the protests and the strike, no interference.
Maybe the Council will finally listen - real talk, not just rules.
Giving people room to breathe is risky, but necessary now.
Let's see if we can reopen trust, Alex.
You helped me remember who suffers in silence. I'll let the disruption happen.
If the city falls into chaos, so be it - at least it's honest.
Surveillance only breeds more fear. Negotiation might plant a seed instead.
I trust the public to show us what order should mean next.
monologue_self: They won't notice what I've permitted.
Some mistakes are meant to last.
I made a personal call. Untraceable for now.
Action matters more than talk at this point.
I'm letting the data strike go through. My call alone.
Maybe it's reckless, but the city must decide its own balance.
I'll watch what grows from this.
No advice swayed me tonight. The system needs a rupture, not patchwork.
Letting in the strike is risky, but my conscience is clear.
Whatever chaos comes is fair payment for our silence.
I wanted to be part of the change itself.
I chose disruption over another quiet betrayal. No one pushed me there - just the weight of years.
Maybe the city has to break to finally heal. I'm done with half-measures.
I owe it to the vanished - to all of us - to let truth grow wild.
Tonight, I accepted chaos over permanent shadow. No more middle road, not for me.

questions.neutral: Are the lines starting to blur?

hobby.message: Typewriters treating you better than people?
Origami help keep the noise out?
Urban exploration ever get boring for you?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Depends what you mean. Some things are clear if you focus.
I fold origami. It's practical, keeps the mind steady.
Was harder today. Not much peace around lately.
The bar is quieter, even the hobby feels off.
Sometimes. I use origami to tune things out, snaps my mind into order.
Today, couldn't stop hearing protests outside. Made mistakes on a fold.
Mostly stick to small cranes, easy to hide in a pocket now.
People notice if you linger too long, even for paper models.
Feels like any calm activity gets shadowed these days.
The lines blur, sure. I fold origami - complex models, keeps my mind sharp.
Usually gives me focus, but lately, riots and access checks keep breaking that calm.
Yesterday, tried a Kawasaki rose and my hands shook halfway through.
Background noise isn't just noise - it's tension, hard to tune out now.
Dropped a model leaving the block and someone handed it back, nervous eye contact.
It's strange when a harmless hobby suddenly gets tangled with what's happening outside.
Yeah, blurry. I've been folding origami since before the Council digitized everything.
Paper's grounding. But stacking modular stars gets tough when patrols bang on the doors.
Last week I tried a six-intersecting-cube build to distract myself. Didn't work.
Noise from the vanished echoes up the stairwell, throws off your count.
Sometimes I make extra, leave them out for someone erased to find.
Felt weird hiding origami as if it marked me out for something.
Now, every fold feels under surveillance, like the system erases even small patterns.
Absolutely, blurring everywhere. I got into origami when the first BCI apps rolled out.
Used to fold elaborate dragons in data centers, just to feel real.
Now, can't focus - protests outside and families missing from our halls.
Yesterday, started a tessellation for an erased neighbor. Quietest I've ever folded.
Finished it, but couldn't deliver. Too many patrols, too many stares.
You know, I memorize fold patterns in case my access gets wiped.
I still dream about placing a model somewhere nobody can erase it.
Feels like every paper fold is a way to record something the system might delete.
hobby_answer: One or two cranes lately. Nothing elaborate.
Hard to focus on it now. Too much happening.
You know how things are with those patrols.
Mostly keep to myself. Just old habits.
Don't need it drawing attention.
Folded some - cranes, yes. Not as many as before.
Patrols check everyone now. Makes you rethink hobbies.
Left one in the hall, vanished by morning.
Feels risky, but it's something familiar.
Too much tension. People suspicious of everything lately.
Yeah, a few origami cranes. I use scrap printouts mostly.
It keeps my hands steady when headlines get ugly.
Heard about the vanished - hard to fold in silence now.
Usually I'd share a model, now I just leave them out.
Feels strange, making something delicate when the city's breaking.
Neighbors started noticing the little things more lately.
It's how I process, I guess.
I've made more than cranes lately - complex stuff, modular stars too.
It's grounding, especially now with all these disappearances.
After Rada's expose, my building feels like a ghost block sometimes.
I left a modular star on the notice ledge, hoping someone erased might see it.
Sometimes I catch myself folding extra points, like I'm trying to count who's missing.
Sharing them openly feels riskier than it used to.
Still, it's how I stay visible - subtle, but real.
Kind of a quiet signal, you know?
Folding origami's always helped me manage the noise, but lately it's different.
Since the erasures and the expose, it feels almost political.
I used to offer models to neighbors. Now most stay hidden inside.
A few days back I left a star with extra points on the ledge - my way of noticing the vanished.
I catch myself counting empty flats as I fold. Too many.
Saw someone take one of my cranes and tuck it into their bag, looking over their shoulder.
Feels like we're all trying to send each other signals nobody says aloud.
Folding is small, but it's an act of memory for me now.
We're all holding onto some piece of proof we exist, you know?

main.opener: Can't help but feel like everyone's carrying something these days. You too?
variants: Not much, really. Just work and... more checks at the building lately.
Feels like everyone's being watched closer than usual.
A few neighbors got some notices slipped under their doors - not sure why.
I just feel so... uncertain now. Like I could disappear and no one would even notice.
Yeah, I guess. Things feel off lately - too many patrols around my place.
Yesterday they asked for physical ID instead of the usual scan. Twice, actually.
A lot of people in my block seem nervous. No one's talking in the hallways anymore.
Some neighbors got review notices. No idea if I'm next.
I just feel so... uncertain now. Like I could disappear and no one would even notice.
I suppose so. They've stepped up checks where I live - patrols wanting papers, that kind of thing.
I heard some people in my building are getting official review notices.
Honestly, it's tense. Folks avoid each other now - like everyone's waiting for something bad to happen.
My BCI score dipped again. Nothing dramatic, but enough to make me nervous about my access.
I keep emergency contacts up to date, just in case something happens to me.
I just feel so... uncertain now. Like I could disappear and no one would even notice.
Yeah, I'm carrying more than I'd like these days. Work's gotten riskier since the announcements about the audit and the 'Vanished.'
The system keeps flagging more of us for minor things. My own BCI score dropped again this week - and it's not exactly high to begin with.
They're questioning everyone - had to show physical ID twice yesterday just to get home.
Neighbors are getting notices about their status. Makes the whole floor feel empty.
I can't trust the system won't just lock me out. I run work on an old disconnected laptop now.
Honestly, I'm scared. I update my emergency contacts each night, just hoping someone would notice if I vanish too.
I just feel so... uncertain now. Like I could disappear and no one would even notice.
Honestly, I never used to think about this kind of thing. I believed the system made things safer, easier - for everyone.

Now, after the audit announcement and seeing people get erased, I can't tell what's safe anymore. Just last night, I was asked for ID at both the entrance and exit of my building. That's never happened before.
My neighbors - they're getting these quiet notices about their eligibility. Some don't come out anymore. Feels like the hallways are haunted.
My own score keeps dropping. I know why - I work in behavioral analysis and... well, I question too much. I used to think Innovator ideas could make things better, but now...
I've stopped contacting anyone I used to trust at work. I do what I have to on an old offline laptop.
Each day I check my access, expecting it to be gone. I keep updating my list of who to call if I'm locked out - because it happens, just like that.
I see the system for what it really is. They say it's rational, but it's making ghosts of us.
I just feel so... uncertain now. Like I could disappear and no one would even notice.
main.emotion: I just feel so... uncertain now. Like I could disappear and no one would even notice.

emotional.opener: You matter, Oksana. Even if the system tries to make you feel invisible, there are still people who see you - really see you.
variants: Thanks. That's... good to hear.
Sometimes it doesn't feel true, but. Okay.
It's strange to hear that out loud.
I'm not used to anyone noticing.
Still, it helps a little.
Appreciate you saying that. It means more than you think.
Most days I just try to blend in, not make a mark.
I guess deep down, I do want someone to notice if I'm gone.
Maybe it's human to need that.
Hearing that from you, it actually gets through.
It's been a while since someone really looked at me, not just my ID or my score.
Most people I know act like we're all the same, interchangeable.
I used to just accept it. Now, I wonder what I'm even disappearing into.
You remind me there's more than the system.
You know, I almost forgot what it's like to be actually seen. Not as a statistic, not as a pattern.
Sometimes I try to remember who I was before the scores and the quiet doubts.
I keep telling myself I don't care, but deep down it eats at me - if I disappear, what am I really leaving behind?
Being noticed. Just that. It feels fragile, precious in all this noise.
I don't admit this to anyone - feeling lost or scared. But you get it, don't you?
Thank you for seeing me, not just the number they assign.

factual.opener: Come on, if something big's happening, what actually is it? You work on this stuff - what do you know?
variants: People are talking about families losing access all at once.
There's been some coverage about records going missing, that's all.
Council says they're doing audits. Not sure what it means for us.
Everyone's on edge. That's about it.
I heard some groups disappeared from the system.
Media picked it up after someone leaked stories about the 'Vanished.'
There are protests. Aid groups popping up, trying to help those locked out.
Council's promising to fix things, but I don't buy it.
Access keeps getting worse in some places.
It's mostly about those 'Vanished' cases now. Whole households erased, nothing left in the system.
That expose made it impossible to ignore. Kind of shocked how fast protests spread.
Apparently, old code is behind the erasures - stuff no one checked for years.
Council's scrambling. There's talk of restoring people, but the trust is gone.
A lot of us believe things need to change. Some in my field wanted more innovation, not this.
Service cutoffs are all over the place now. Some areas get hit daily.
It's the BCI, obviously. The prototype code was never fully cleared - and now we're seeing mass disappearances.
People's entire histories wiped. Once you're gone from the BCI, nothing works - housing, medical, work, gone.
After the expose, there's been riots, mass aid camps forming wherever people gather.
Council can't even pretend it's under control. They're looking at audits, but no one believes it matters.
I always thought the Innovator approach would help - rethink the system. Now I'm not sure that even matters.
I've seen too much inside. Access failures aren't random - patterns repeat in the worst ways.
Every department's plugging leaks instead of fixing root problems.
They never fixed the old BCI prototypes. That's where the mass erasures started - bad code, no oversight.
I see the reports. Families just vanish from every record, and the system acts like they never existed.
Internal data shows even Council members' details leaked. Now they're just blaming each other.
People are living in camps, waiting for a fix that may not come. I know those aid groups can't keep up.
The official audit announcement was just damage control. There's no process that can restore trust now.
Most of us who work with BCI data know it's not neutral. Still, some on the Council cling to Harmonist slogans like it means anything.
Innovators wanted deeper changes, but it all fell apart after Halden. I'm not sure what I believe now.
The BCI doesn't just predict - sometimes it erases. Secrets get buried, then surface again, like now.
I've stopped reporting certain anomalies. Feels pointless with how broken it all is.
